intro: Sida brittonii, commonly known as the Britton's mallows, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Its leaves are usually ovate to lanceolate, with a hairy texture, and the flowers range in color from white to pink. Sida brittonii is adapted to drought conditions and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
